title: Ticket #6732: speed up the schedd check for a change in an autoclustered attribute
description:
Stats from a busy CMS Schedd show that we are spending quite a bit of time determining if a SetAttribute call is changing a significant attribute of a job. 
from Brian's email
  - We spend a good chunk of time reading off the next setAttribute command from the socket.
    Would be useful to be able to batch attribute updates.
  - A shocking amount of time is going to AutoCluster::preSetAttribute.
    Seems that we are re-parsing the list of significant attributes
   (allocating lists and strings galore) to see if the changed attribute is
    in the list of sigattrs.  Could we not turn this into a hashmap lookup?
     String search?  If we bulk-processed updates, we could at least re-parse
     the list only once.
  - To quantify, it seems we are paying 0.5ms per attribute.
    I'm seeing 13 - 45ms per shadow update -- seems small, but adds up to 1
    week of processing time since the schedd was restarted a month ago.
    In the worst case, that implies the schedd could do nothing else but
    process shadow updates at somewhere between 20 and 100Hz.
    Roughly estimating from strace, I see up to 50Hz sometimes.
    This matches with the stats below.

Brian
Examination of this code shows that there is a lot of room for improvement here.

The proposed solution is twofold

  1. optimize preSetAttribute by doing the check without allocating any memory

  2. Skip calling preSetAttribute entirely for running jobs, and instead always invalidate the autocluster id whenever a job goes back into idle state. Perhaps we could keep a flag on the job object to indicate whether any attributes were changed while non-idle? Or maybe this is unnecessary, since jobs go back into idle so infrequently.
